The guide covers how to install Blue Planet ROA platform and solutions in a geo-redundant (GR) setup environment on Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Microsoft Azure.

Geographic Redundancy is the replication of your data in two geographically separate and interconnected sites to ensure that your data remains intact and is always available if a disaster happens. In the case of a disaster, your applications immediately switches from the impacted site to the redundant or standby site.

The installation of ROA involves starting AWS Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) instances or Azure virtual machines, performing configurations related to the operating system (OS), performing GR configurations, and then installing the ROA platform and solution.
This chapter covers the recommended guidelines and requirements to install Blue Planet Route Optimization and Analysis (BP-ROA) on Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Microsoft Azure.

In the most common configuration, ROA peers with a network Interior Gateway Protocol (IGP) — Intermediate System to Intermediate System (ISIS) or Open Shortest Path First (OSPF), to gather real time network connectivity data. Use of IGP peering is a preferred option for IGP data collection as the ROA system discovers changes in the network in real-time, as quickly as the routers themselves discover network changes.

To access remote IGP areas, usually Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) tunnels are built across the network. AWS supports the use of GRE tunnels, but Microsoft Azure does not currently allows the use of GRE tunnels.

Border Gateway Protocol - Link State (BGP-LS) is also supported as an alternative to IGP peering by both AWS and Microsoft Azure. While BGP-LS may not report network changes as quickly as IGP peering, it does not require direct peering with remote IGP areas; so GRE tunnels are not required. This method is supported by both AWS ad Azure.
This section covers the recommended guidelines you must follow before you begin the installation of Blue Planet Route Optimization and Analysis (BP-ROA) on AWS instances or Azure virtual machines.
This section covers the requirements to set up Blue Planet ROA (BP-ROA) on AWS instances and Azure virtual machines. These requirements are based on the following environments:

The following tables list the recommended AWS and Azure instance types and required resources based on the instance size. The instance size is determined by a number of factors related to the customer network size and complexity.
Factors such as the number of advertised IP prefixes, number of MPLS tunnels, number of VPN services, and collection of performance and/or IP Flow data (Netflow) determine the required instance size.
Contact your Ciena account representative for questions about server requirements.

The instance type c5n.9xlarge or c5n.18xlarge is required only for very high network throughput. A larger disk size will allow ROA to store more historical data for planning and post-mortem analysis. Please work with your Blue Planet Account team to determine the storage requirements for your system.
To ensure that the HA functionality works properly, the following configurations are required:
This section covers information about ports that must be kept open to allow communication among ROA hosts and components. These ports include:
The following table lists ports and services they provide:
Domain Name Systems (DNS) client. Allows the Blue Planet server to resolve names.
Dynamic Host Control Protocol (DHCP) client. Allows the Blue Planet server to get IP addresses through DHCP. This port is optional.
Network Time Protocol (NTP) client. Used to set the time on the Blue Planet server.
Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) server. Used to monitor Blue Planet server.

Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) server. Used to send SNMP Traps. SNMP Traps are the most frequently used alert messages sent from a remote SNMP-enabled device (an agent) to a central collector, the “SNMP manager.”
Secure Socket Shell (SSH) server. Used to get administrator-level access to the Blue Planet server.

File Transfer Protocol (FTP). Used to upload data files to the server including uploading backup images for restoration, or for certain software upgrades. This port is used by the “Correlate Time Series” feature of the ROA GUI.
The FTP access is granted only to specific user accounts as configured by the administrator. The FTP server is disabled by default unless explicitly enabled from the Administration web pages.
The system does not allow logins through telnet.

TACACS+, an authentication, authorization and accounting (AAA) protocol. The master unit in a distributed system can provide user authentication service to the client units in the system. The interactions are encrypted by a shared secret.

Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP). This port is used to provide initial Web access to the Route Explorer. Most access to the application is encrypted and is restricted to authorized (password-authenticated) users only.

Broader Gateway Protocol (BGP). Used by Route Explorer boxes that are configured to record BGP data. This allows connections from potential BGP peers. This port is open on any interface configured for BGP recording.
Secure Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTPS). Used to get encrypted access to ROA’s administration and reporting web pages.

Label Distribution Protocol (LDP). This port opens when configured on a Flow Recorder unit to collect Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) label information on a VPN service provider’s network. The communication is not encrypted.

Raw Flow Server. This port opens on a Flow Recorder to allow the Modelling Engine to fetch information from the database of raw traffic flows. This uses a proprietary protocol. The communication is not encrypted.

Used for the query API communications. The Queries are password-protected. The password can be encrypted or sent as plain text. This functionality is disabled by default. You must enable it, if required, through the Queries web page.

MySQL. Various “distributed configuration” setups (with multiple units being partially configured and operated in a coordinated fashion) need to allow each other remote database access. This access is protected by the use of public-key pairs for access and authentication.

MySQL. When database replication is enabled in a distributed Route Explorer system with multiple Route Recorder units, multiple MySQL servers run, each with their own ports. This creates replicas from each recorder and allow access to those replicas. Inter-unit MySQL communication is protected by SSL encryption.

Used to access a single or shared instance of the ROA GUI using a Java VNC (Virtual Network Computing) viewer. Access to this service is optional and disabled by default. When the service is enabled, access is password-protected.

Used to access multiple instances of the ROA GUI through a VNC viewer. This access is optional and disabled by default. When the service is enabled, access is protected with same set of usernames and passwords configured for X/SSH and web access.
Open-source in-memory data structure storage. This port can be open on the Master host only if clients have a GUI license in your ROA configuration.

Flow Analyzer Configuration Manager, an internal component of Traffic Explorer that allows configuration changes to the Flow Analyzer daemon from the Master Modeling Engine unit. This port is open only if the Flow Analyzer daemon is running. DES- CBC encrypted with a fixed secret.
Used to integrate ROA with the Multi Domain Service Orchestration (MDSO) platform.

Used by X-Display Manager Control Protocol (XDMCP). This port is open when when the VNC viewer displays the numbers 2 through 10. However, access control within the xdm(1) configuration restricts any access from remote machines.

X-Display Manager Control Protocol (XDMCP). This port is open when the VNC viewer displays number 2 through 10. However, access control within the xdm(1) configuration restricts any access from remote machines.
Syslog. Reception of Syslog messages from routers is enabled if configured as part of the RSVP-TE feature to track changes in tunnels. The port number is configurable.
A web browsing port primarily used for HTTP service, which provides enables data transmission in plain text.
A web browsing port primarily used for HTTPS service, which provides encryption and transport over secure ports.
Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) tunnel between hosts. For host-to-host connectivity over GRE, IP connectivity must be available. TCP or UDP ports are not required.
A web browsing port primarily used for HTTP service, which provides enables data transmission in plain text.
A web browsing port primarily used for HTTPS service, which provides encryption and transport over secure ports.
Secure Socket Shell (SSH) server. Used to get administrator-level access to the Blue Planet server.
A web browsing port primarily used for HTTPS service, which provides encryption and transport over secure ports.
Standard IPsec Internet Key Exchange //(IKE) port

Used for ping echo request and reply. The Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) types — Type 8 (Echo Message) and Type 0 (Echo Reply Message), are used for ping operations. The sender or pinger creates an ICMP packet with type 8 which requests the remote system to return an ICMP reply.
If a firewall exists on the network path between geo-redundant (GR) sites, you (or your administrator) must configure it to allow IPsec traffic. You can usually do this by configuring the following:

Port Address Translation (PAT) is not supported between GR sites, and Encapsulating Security Payload (IP ID 50) is used for data encryption. Moreover, Ciena does not recommend using VPNs with Network Address Translation (NAT) on the network path between GR sites.
To install BP-ROA for cloud deployment, you must install a Ciena license server to extract the BP-ROA files from the tar files.

content.text: This chapter covers the procedures required to create instances or virtual machines (VMs) on Amazon Web Service (AWS) and Microsoft Azure for deploying Blue Planet Route Optimization and Assurance (ROA).You can deploy ROA using a marketplace image and base image provided by Blue Planet.
To deploy Blue Planet ROA using the marketplace image, you must perform steps from scratch, such as installing and configuring an operating system, creating users, and configure disks.
To deploy Blue Planet ROA using the Blue Planet base image, the operating system is pre-installed and configured in the base image.
Based on your preferred deployment method, refer to one of the following sections:
Contact your Ciena account representative if you have questions about license server requirements.

This chapter covers the pre-installation procedures required to deploy Blue Planet ROA on AWS instances or Azure VMs.
The following table provides an overview to the installation procedures and where you perform them.
This section covers how to create the bpadmin user. The bpadmin user with full sudo access is required to install ROA applications and then create the bpuser, which has limited sudo access.
For multi-host deployment, create a bpadmin user on each host where you want to install ROA. Use the same bpadmin password on all hosts.
You must have a password that you want to assign for the bpadmin user.
For multi-host deployments, repeat this procedure on each host. Use the same bpadmin password on all hosts.
This section covers how to configure the swappiness property of Linux kernal.

The swappiness parameter defines how much and how frequently your Linux kernel copies RAM contents for the purpose of swapping. The higher the swappiness value, the faster your Linux kernel performs the swap operation.
This section explains how to disable the firewalld, the default firewall on Red Hat Enterprise Linux.
Before you start, verify that you have root user access.
If the firewall is enabled and running, enter the following command to stop firewall:
Enter the folloing command to disable the firewall:
For multi-host deployment, complete steps 1 to 4 on each host.
This section covers the Secured Socket Shell (SSH) and how to enable the SSH password.
Some cloud server providers, such as Amazon, disable the SSH password authentication by default. For those providers, you can log in over SSH only by using public key authentication.

Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) runs over SSH, and the SFTP passwords do not work by default when SSH password authentication is disabled. Therefore, you must enable the SSH password authentication for bpadmin and bpuser.
To enable the SSH password authentication:
In case of multi-host deployment, repeat this procedure on each host.
This section covers how to configure disk partitioning for AWS instances and Azure VMs.
NAME MAJ:MIN RM SIZE RO TYPE MOUNTPOINT
The following output displays for Azure:
NAME MAJ:MIN RM SIZE RO TYPE MOUNTPOINT

\u251c\u2500sda2 8:2 0 29G 0 part / \u251c\u2500sda14 8:14 0 4M 0 part \u2514\u2500sda15 8:15 0 495M 0 part /boot/efi sdb 8:16 0 64G 0 disk \u2514\u2500sdb1 8:17 0 64G 0 part /mnt/resource sdc 8:32 0 1.2T 0 disk
In the above output, nvme1n1 and sdc are the second 1.2 TB storage volume in AWS and Azure, respectively
lvcreate -L + 100G •n var vg_sys lvcreate -L + 900G •n optciena vg_sys

content.text: echo "/dev/mapper/vg_sys-var /var/log xfs defaults 0 0" >> /etc/fstab echo "/dev/mapper/vg_sys-optciena /opt/ciena xfs defaults 0 0" >> /etc/fstab
content.header: 8. Ensure LVMs are mounted after reboot:

header: 9. Enable swap space and verify that swap is configured correctly. Create a swapfile it it is not created.

content.text: ;create a swap file sudo dd if=/dev/zero of=/mnt/resource/swapfile count=8192 bs=1MiB ;set up the file for swapspace sudo mkswap /mnt/resource/swapfile ;set appropriate permissions on the swapfile sudo chmod 600 /mnt/resource/swapfile ;automatically mount the file as swap area on startup echo '/mnt/resource/swapfile none swap sw 0 0' | sudo tee -a /etc/fstab

This section covers procedures to set up geographical redundancy (GR) between active site and standby site and install ROA platform and solutions on single host or multiple hosts.

You can choose to install one ROA active site or two ROA sites in one workflow. When you install two sites, of which, one is an active site and the other is a standby site, then that is a GR supported ROA site.

content.text: This section covers how to modify the volume group name when the unallocated physical extents (PE) space is left free for ROA to create and configure the Docker thin pool. The volume group name is important because it might be used to restore data on another system.
Ciena recommends you to use unique names that can be easily recognized across multiple virtual groups.
You can use the Linux vgdisplay command to display volume group information. Execute this procedure only on host 0.
To modify the volume group name:
This section covers how to configure the Network Time Protocol (NTP) server to be used as timing source for ROA hosts on Amazon AWS.
All ROA hosts must be synchronized to an accurate timing source. The ROA hosts can use a local or remote time source.
By default, the ROA installer sets up four NTP servers:
Although you can specify your own NTP servers, Ciena recommends that you always have a minimum of three, preferably four, timing servers for optimal ROA timing synchronization.
The following lists the number of upstream servers available in order of most to least preferred:
Disable all other timing synchronization methods including, but not limited to, VMware Tools periodic time synchronization.
After the installation, you can use the bp2-site check-platform or bp2-site check-clock-drift commands to check ROA timing synchronization.
This section provides a procedure to set a local time source or custom remote time sources (different from the default ones provided).
Before you start, ensure that you:
# By default, NTP will be configured if the number of hosts listed in the hosts file is > 1.
# There are 2 options 'remote' (default) and 'local'. The default configuration (remote) will set up NTP to connect
# to a set of remote, Operating System specific, servers. If local is specified, host0 will be used as the ntp clock
# reference for all nodes in the cluster. This is controlled via the 'ntp_server_type' outlined below. #
Here is an example before the edit for the custom remote time sources. The example focuses on the section to be edited.
# In the 'remote' case, you can also override the set of remote servers by uncommenting and setting the
# 'ntp_servers_custom' variable and configuring 1,3 or 4 NTP servers to connect to.
Here is an example after the edit, using hostnames. The first NTP server to be contacted will be the one with the fully qualified domain name of 0.mycustomer.ntp.com:
Here is an example after the edit, using IP addresses. The first NTP server to be contacted will be the one with an IP address of 10.128.8.89:

######## # site # ######## # In the 'remote' case, you can also override the set of remote servers by uncommenting and setting the # 'ntp_servers_custom' variable and configuring 1,3 or 4 NTP servers to connect to. ntp_servers_custom:

header: Configuring the Blue Planet email service

content.text: This section covers how to configure the Blue Planet email service. You must configure the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) server to allow ROA to send system emails to users. These emails are used for alarm notifications and forgotten password assistance.
content.header: Configuring the Blue Planet email service
Configuring the Blue Planet email service

content.text: Before you start, ensure that you:
content.header: Configuring the Blue Planet email service
Configuring the Blue Planet email service

content.text: To configure the Blue Planet email service:
content.header: Configuring the Blue Planet email service
Configuring the Blue Planet email service
Configuring the Blue Planet email service
Configuring the Blue Planet email service

content.text: Account username used to send emails.
The SMTP server static path value. The value must be set to /bp2/src/static. Do not change this value.
The SMTP server authentication. Set the value to true.
The SMTP server transport security. Set the value to true or false, as applicable.
The SMTP server fully qualified domain name (FQDN), such as smtp.gmail.com or, if a dedicated SMTP server, an FQDN that you own.
The SMTP server mailer name. The value must be set to Blue Planet Mailer. Do not change this value.
The SMTP server port number. Depending on the server, this port can be 25, 465, or 587.

The SMTP server email account from which reset password emails are sent. Some SMTP servers, such as Gmail, allow you to use an alias that is not set on the server. For example, the account could be bphostmonitor@abccompany.com, but the value could be api-crinoid@ciena.com.
Here is an example before the edit:

# SMTP configuration details for 'Forgot Password' feature smtp_username: USERNAME smtp_password: PASSWORD smtp_staticPath: /bp2/src/static smtp_authen: SMTP_AUTHENTICATION smtp_transport: SMTP_TRANSPORTSECURITY smtp_mail_server: MAILSERVER.COM smtp_mailer_name: MAILER_NAME smtp_port: SMTP_PORT smtp_email: MAILER@EMAIL.COM
Here is an example after the edit:

# SMTP configuration details for 'Forgot Password' feature smtp_username: GmailUser smtp_password: AnyPassword smtp_staticPath: /bp2/src/static smtp_authen: true smtp_transport: true smtp_mail_server: smtp.gmail.com smtp_mailer_name: Blue Planet Mailer smtp_port: 587 smtp_email: api-crinoid@AnyCompany.com

content.text: This section covers how to set up users. Complete the following procedure to manage keys of the bpadmin user and the root user, create the bpuser user (sudo restricted Docker install user), and manage its sudo permissions and keys.

header: Configuring a site IP for Amazon AWS

content.text: This chapter covers how to configure a site IP for AWS.
content.header: Configuring a site IP for Amazon AWS

content.text: A site IP is a virtual IP address that is provided over HTTP to access virtual machines on AWS cloud. This IP address is not statically associated with any single host on a site. Instead, if the host associated with an IP fails, the IP dynamically maps to other active hosts, ensuring that the site is always operational.
content.header: Configuring a site IP for Amazon AWS

content.text: To complete the deployment of Blue Planet ROA on AWS, you must configure the site IP for AWS. To do that, you must create a new policy, create an AWS IAM user, and then apply the necessary configuration.

header: Configuring a floating private IP for Microsoft Azure

content.text: This chapter covers how to configure floating private IP for Azure. The floating IP mechanism for Azure operates by adding or removing IP configurations in the network interface card of the Azure virtual machines.
content.header: Configuring a floating private IP for Microsoft Azure

content.text: To configure a floating private IP, you must set multiple configurations in the Azure portal.
content.header: Configuring a floating private IP for Microsoft Azure
